message: Happy New Year to all my constituents in #FL26. I’m grateful to have the honor and privilege of representing our community for another year, and I look forward to all the things to come in 2017.

Honored to meet with Kimberly Motley, an international human rights attorney who has represented victims around the world and was recently arrested and detained while conducting her work in Cuba. Thank you for giving these victims a voice.

I'm honored to be selected by my colleagues to serve as a member of the powerful Committee on Ways and Means in the new Congress. This position will allow me to advocate for many issues of importance to my constituents and our South Florida community. I look forward to working with my Republican and Democratic colleagues to advance bipartisan solutions that will better the lives of those in my district and across the country.

My colleague Congressman Ted Deutch and I met with French Ambassador to the U.S. Gérard Araud today to discuss the U.S.-French partnership to battle #ClimateChange and the importance of American energy efficient technology.

I was proud to join the majority of my colleagues today to take a stand against the Obama Administration's unprecedented and shameful abandonment of Israel. The resolution we adopted today condemns the Administration's actions, expresses the House's support for our ally Israel, and sends a clear message to the world that the overwhelming majority of American legislators stand with her.

Leaving a blue candle lit in my office window tonight for #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay. Thankful to all our men and women in law enforcement, especially Miami-Dade Police Department, Homestead Police Department and MCSO - Florida Keys  in #FL26, who sacrifice to protect and serve our community.

Did you read today’s Miami Herald editorial? American generosity has been abused for far too long. Grateful to have Senator Marco Rubio as a partner on this issue, and looking forward to reintroducing and continuing to build support for our legislation in this Congress.

South Florida families deserve the confidence of knowing that there are measures in place to protect them when they walk around Miami. This is exactly why I introduced my Safe Streets initiative, which was signed into law in 2015, to encourages states and transportation planning commissions to adopt construction plans to protect the safety of both motorized and non-motorized users.   Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2iGqYLq

Many people’s respect for our environment has started with a love of our National Parks. Excited for all the new Biscayne National Park visitors who will learn about the importance of Biscayne Bay and our South Florida ecosystem during their visit.

Today, I joined with 101 of my colleagues to urge President-Elect Donald J. Trump to move the American embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem immediately upon assuming office. A step that is all the more urgent given the Obama Administration's anti-Israel actions on the United Nations Security Council last month.

Last year I recognized Edward Knight of the Florida Keys on the House Floor. Ed, as many called him, would have turned 100 years old today. As a leader, businessman, and philanthropist, Ed was a true staple in our community. While we lost him last year, his service will continue to be deeply appreciated for generations to come.

Always great to have snacks from home to get me through the week! Thanks to FIU in Washington, D.C. for dropping off Vicky Bakery yesterday! With over 33,000 alumni, 13,000 students and 3,000 faculty and staff in #FL26, I'm proud to advocate for Florida International University here in Washington.

For two years, I have demanded a solution to this crisis from the Administration. Instead, the Administration chose to wait until the last hour to act, and as usual collaborated directly with the Cuban dictatorship instead of consulting members of Congress. America’s policy toward Cuba should serve to advance U.S. interests, and it should never be coordinated with anti-American dictators.  Although our country's immigration policy toward Cuba has granted many of the dictatorship's victims refuge, it has also been grossly abused and exploited by many Cuban nationals, while also inadvertently bolstering the Cuban regime. A change to this policy was inevitable. I remain firmly committed to supporting the victims of persecution in Cuba while ending all abuses of America’s generosity.

En multiples ocasiones le exigí una solución a la Casa Blanca y evidentemente han esperado hasta el ultimo momento para actuar. Como ya es de costumbre, el gobierno de Obama lo ha colaborado todo con la dictadura cubana y en ningún momento consultó al Congreso. La política de este país hacia Cuba debe servir para avanzar los intereses de EEUU y no debe ser coordinada con dictadores anti-americanos.   Si bien la política migratoria de EEUU hacia Cuba ha favorecido a muchas víctimas de la dictadura, también ha sido objeto de abuso y fraude e inadvertidamente ha avanzado los intereses de los opresores del pueblo cubano. Un cambio era inevitable. En el Congreso seguiremos trabajando para reformar esta política con fin de apoyar a las víctimas de la persecución y de frenar todos los abusos contra la generosidad de EEUU.
Joining my colleagues to discuss our newly introduced BRIDGE Act, legislation protecting DREAMers from the fear of deportation while Congress continues to debate comprehensive immigration reform.

With the increasing probability of foreign nations drilling near our shores, American taxpayers across the country are at risk of footing the bill to bail out the mistakes of foreign oil companies. Yesterday US Rep Darren Soto and I introduced our bipartisan Foreign Spill Protection Act, a bill to ensure that won’t happen and guarantees our coastal communities will have the resources they need for clean up and recovery if they are affected by a foreign spill.

Over the last several years, many Americans have learned the hard way that having an insurance policy is not the same as having access to quality healthcare. While Obamacare had some positive reforms, including coverage for preexisting conditions and allowing children to remain on their parents’ plans longer, this law is falling apart. My office has received many complaints over the last two years about our current healthcare system, and I have no doubt that all Americans - especially the most vulnerable - deserve better. Quite simply, the Affordable Care Act has broken its promise to lower costs and offer more and better choices to the American people.   Today’s budget reconciliation package is an important first step in building a truly patient-centered healthcare system that lowers the costs of care, expands access to providers, puts consumers in control, and respects our doctors and healthcare professionals. Unlike Obamacare, our reform legislation will not be written by health insurance companies, hospitals, pharmaceutical companies or other special interests. Instead it will be written for American families who need and deserve quality healthcare.
Had a great time at the Key West Seafood Festival yesterday. No better place for fresh seafood than the Florida Keys! Thanks to all who came out to support our local businesses and fishermen.
Today we honor Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. A great American, whose strength and perseverance continues to remind each of us to stand for our convictions. #MLKDay

I was proud to participate in my first Committee on Ways and Means meeting last week. Looking forward to working with my Republican and Democratic colleagues on the Committee to advance bipartisan solutions that will better the lives of those in my district and across the country. Learn more about my appointment to this influential committee here: http://bit.ly/2iTYDBJ

Enjoyed attending Mayor Carlos Gimenez’s State of the County address today to hear about the progress and future of Miami-Dade County, Fla. I’m honored to represent a portion of this thriving county in Congress and I look forward to working with county leaders to increase public transit options for my constituents and the many other federal issues facing our community in the coming years.

My office has given out almost 200 inauguration tickets to constituents coming to Washington for the President-Elect's swearing in!  Be sure to plan ahead your transportation for that morning and know where you need to go. If you received tickets from my office and have any questions, please give us a call.
Joined colleagues on both sides of the aisle to witness the peaceful transition of power this past Friday.

Congratulations to Monroe County officials for taking this positive step to prepare our community's infrastructure for the effects of climate change. I look forward to continuing to partner with you in this effort.

Our Climate Solutions Caucus has gained great momentum only a few weeks into the new Congress! This group is working together to find solutions that will protect our environment and unleash a new era of American innovation.

This week is #SchoolChoice Week. Every child in America, regardless of their background or zip code, deserves access to a quality school, and families deserve access to opportunities that will prepare their children for success.

As hundreds of thousands prepare to march on Washington to be a voice for the unborn later this week, my colleagues and I passed a bill that would eliminate taxpayer funding for abortions while protecting women’s health funding for clinics offering other services.

I highlighted Monroe County constituent Emilie's struggles with the Affordable Care Act at my first Committee on Ways and Means hearing today. Emilie recently shared with me that she is paying over $700 per month for a plan with a deductible that is over $6000, but still she has been unable to find a doctor in her area who will accept her insurance. Even though she has insurance, her options are severely limited and premiums continue to increase. We need to improve our healthcare system to make it more affordable for all.

After so many years of heated debate, it's time for Congress to come together and produce results on immigration reform. Senator Tillis is working with both parties to try and build a broad proposal that will tighten border security and enforce our immigration laws, while also providing certainty and relief for immigrants who have been contributing to our country's economy. I applaud his effort to build consensus on a solution and I look forward to continuing to work with him on this issue.
Thank you to all of those participating in the #MarchforLife today. We must remember #WhyWeMarch not just today, but every day.

In these times of great political division in our country, reducing the regulatory burden on families and employers is something that brings most Americans together. It’s why I supported the REINS Act, which ensures an up-or-down vote on major regulations, earlier this year and why my colleagues and I in the House will continue to review and repeal harmful, job-killing regulations in the coming months.
Here's a sneak peak at today's weekly newsletter. If you want to receive updates from my office about what's going on in Washington and around #FL26, sign up on my website: curbelo.house.gov/

Had a great meeting today with Bradley Whitford and Citizens Climate Lobby to discuss the growing momentum of the Climate Change Solutions caucus I co-founded with Congressman Ted Deutch last Congress.

My office has been working diligently with the U.S. Navy to ensure affordable housing options are available for all #KeyWest residents. This is a priority for our community and I will remain actively engaged until we can come to a solution.

When constituents and dedicated public servants come to us with a problem, we’re committed to doing everything in our power to work toward a solution that makes sense for our community. This postponement will give our local fishermen and guides a chance to make adjustments to incorporate these rules into their business.
Under the previous Administration, U.S. interests & human rights took a back seat to accommodating the Castro regime. A full review of U.S.-Cuba policy is in order and this is a positive step.

On Friday my colleagues and I introduced the Authorization for Use of Military Force against ISIS. Radical Islamic terrorism is still on the rise, and it’s critical the Commander in Chief is not restricted in his capabilities to use the full might of our armed forces necessary to eradicate this threat.
Today would have been the 106th birthday of President Ronald Reagan. Remembering him and everything he stood for today.

Our oceans are a source of hope and opportunity for all Americans.  We cannot let the toxic political environment distract us from that simple fact. We can all support and work towards policies that protect American fishermen, reduce the amount of plastic going into the ocean, fund coastal communities so they can respond to the threats of ocean acidification and sea level rise, and contribute to improving our communities by cleaning up our coasts and waterways.
Had a productive conversation with Philippe Cousteau about bipartisan solutions to #climatechange and ocean issues at Ocean Conservancy's event in Washington.

Great questions from the students of Our Lady of Lourdes Academy today. Had a chance to speak with them about my day-to-day in Washington and what's going on in politics during their visit to the Capitol with the Close Up - Washington D.C. Educational Programs.

As the father of two young daughters, I’ve seen firsthand how the Internet has become a part of children’s lives earlier than ever before. Programs like the one I participated in at W.R. Thomas Middle School this morning give parents and our students the resources to practice safe and secure online habits.

Joined Ileana Ros-Lehtinen and Senator Menendez in urging President Donald J. Trump to consider a number of actions in support of Venezuelans suffering under the regime of Nicolas Maduro, including stronger sanctions on human rights violators.

Belen Jesuit alumnus Jason is now serving as a United States Air Force pilot and stopped by my office to present me with a flag that was flown during a refueling mission over Iraq and Syria. Thank you for your service and for sharing this symbol of liberty with the people of #FL26.
In case you missed it, from the Miami Herald yesterday: "Curbelo has been a leading Republican voice speaking in favor of finding solutions to combat climate change."
Earlier this week, I met with the parents of Hadar Goldin, an Israeli soldier who was killed by Hamas and has been withholding his body every since. Hamas must release his body to his family.
Recently spoke with OpportunityLives about my appointment to the Committee on Ways and Means, the future of the Affordable Care Act, trade, and more.
Did you catch CBS4 Local's coverage of my online safety event at W.R. Thomas Middle School last week? This is a great program and you can learn more here: http://bit.ly/2lB7CsW
The lessons we learned as a nation during Lincoln's presidency are at the core of who we are as Americans. On his birthday we are reminded we must do everything we can to honor his legacy.

The rise to power of Tareck El Aissami has been an alarming development for anyone desiring a future of freedom, democracy, and dignity for the Venezuelan people. These sanctions send a strong message of solidarity to the people of Venezuela and against the gangsters who have destroyed that country and brought so many Venezuelans to the point of starvation. I’m grateful the Administration took such swift action after my colleagues and I urged the President to sanction this Maduro thug last week. I look forward to continuing to work with this Administration to prioritize human rights and hold corrupt regimes accountable.

One of the greatest blemishes on human history is the genocide that has taken place in Syria over the last few years. Over 500,000 human beings have died, including approxiamtely 50,000 children. More than ten million people have been displaced, resulting in a refugee crisis that has destabilized Europe and put gruesome images on our television and phone screens, all while ISIS grew and inspired terror throughout the world. Our country, under the leadership of President Obama, and our democratic allies around the world share the blame in this. Obama clearly stated there would be serious consequences if Bashar al Assad used chemical weapons against civilians – it was one of his Administration’s red lines. Assad proceeded to do just that, gassing innocent people to death including children with total impunity. While many opinion leaders implored the civilized world to act, warning the consequences of inaction were far greater than the consequences of action, only the French expressed a willingness to intervene.   Not only did the Obama Administration fail to act at that critical point in 2013, they also invited the Russians into the conflict. For three more years innocent Syrians were bombed to death by Assad and Russian military forces. Hospitals and schools were destroyed, and the civilized world just watched as Aleppo and others cities burned.  In short, with few exceptions, Obama and other world leaders - including those of majority Muslim countries - turned their backs on the Syrian people. It was shameful and unforgivable and will have many harmful ramifications for years to come. The lesson is American leadership is necessary in the world. Serious world conflicts we ignore will eventually show up in our homeland.   There are many Americans expressing outrage at the new Administration’s executive orders issued hastily their first week in office. I understand these legitimate concerns. I also wonder if these same Americans were as adamant, or if they raised their voices at all, while the previous Administration patiently observed the genocide of the Syrian people. The new Administration should learn from these terrible missteps of the past. We should demand intense vetting of Syrian refugees, not summarily reject them all – especially not precious children who deserve a future. We should also accept - not shy away from - our responsibility as the greatest nation on the face of the Earth.

I spoke with experts at a Committee on Ways and Means hearing today about the increasing challenges of combating suburban poverty, like that found in South Florida. More strategic funding of public transportation and increasing the recognition of career and technical education options are just two of the possible options the experts and I discussed.
Students visiting Washington from Christopher Columbus High School joined me in the Committee on Ways and Means hearing room today to discuss their questions about government and politics.
‪Today we honor Presidents Washington and Lincoln, men whose humble leadership should inspire us all. Happy #PresidentsDay!‬

I'm telling this Administration the same thing I told the previous Administration: If we're going to solve the immigration puzzle in this country, something we've been debating for about ten years now, the Administration has to engage Congress, the solution has to come out of Congress, and the solution has to be complete.

My colleagues and I on the Committee on Ways and Means want to build a simpler, flatter, and more fair tax code, so that people across #FL26 can dedicate more time to their families and can have more resources to get ahead instead of just getting by.
Factual and rational comments shouldn't be rare in today's politics. I'm committed to doing everything I can to make them the norm, and I hope you'll join me.
Met with immigrant entrepreneurs yesterday at Venture Hive to discuss the pivotal contributions immigrants make to our economy in South Florida and across the country.

This is a disappointing choice for the Administration to make. We should be working toward ensuring all American children feel safe and accepted in their schools, regardless of where they live, their race, creed, gender identity or sexual orientation.

Yesterday, I met with two Syrian refugee families as well as representatives from the International Rescue Committee that have been assisting them. These families were God-fearing people who have been thoroughly vetted, love our country, and appreciate our country. We should demand intense vetting of Syrian refugees, not summarily reject them all – especially not precious children who deserve a future. We should also accept - not shy away from - our responsibility as the greatest nation on the face of the Earth.

We each have a responsibility to speak out for what we believe in. I will continue to advocate for South Florida's immigrant community and I'm ready to work with the Administration to ensure we can find a comprehensive, bipartisan solution to reform our immigration system.

The rise of anti-Semitism and violence directed toward our Jewish community is unacceptable to me and should have no place in American society or anywhere in the world. I’m committed to defending the religious freedom and safety of our Jewish community, and my staff and I are ready to help anyway we can to assist and show that we will not tolerate these actions in South Florida.

Most of the Affordable Care Act doesn’t impact the territories, but the Health Insurance Tax is one of a small number of provisions that does, and it’s hurting families in our U.S. territories who are trying to get ahead. These residents are subject to the burdens of the Affordable Care Act, but they do not have access to the benefits.  We must provide relief to those who are incorrectly exposed to this burdensome tax. This bill will fix that.

Following the President's mention of the national debt in last night’s #JointAddress, I took to the House floor today to urge my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to join me and work with the new Administration to address our growing national debt and get America’s fiscal house in order.
Took to the House floor to highlight Monroe County's leadership on incorporating sea level rise into future transportation infrastructure projects.

Reintroduced the Flood Insurance Fairness Act with Congressman Charlie Crist today. Across the country rental properties like those affected by this bill not only serve as primary income for many landlords, but also provide reasonably priced housing for the workforce in our coastal communities. This legislation is critical to #FL26, especially for residents of the Florida Keys that are in desperate need of affordable housing options.

For districts like FL26 and especially areas like the Florida Keys, an adequately funded U.S. Coast Guard is fundamental. I have consistently advocated and voted in support of increases to the Coast Guard’s budget since joining Congress, and I’m going to work hard to make sure that continues to be a priority in the budget and that Congress rejects the Administration's notion that we should cut funds from our Coasties.
Join me in celebrating the incredible achievements and contributions of women around the world and in our daily lives not just today, on #InternationalWomensDay, but everyday.

Yesterday, the Committee on Ways and Means on which I serve and the House Committee on Energy and Commerce began considering legislation that seeks to expand healthcare choices, improve quality, lower costs, and empower low- and middle-income Americans who do not have access to employee or government sponsored healthcare. It is our goal to empower individuals and families, so they can choose the best healthcare plan for themselves. For me, this is simply about providing a better healthcare system for our country – especially for working Americans who struggle to find access to quality healthcare. This is only the first step in finding a better healthcare solution for our country. I invite you to share your thoughts and views as this #BetterCare proposal makes its way through the legislative process because it's so important we get this right.

These are America’s children, and that is why I’m proud to lead this group of representatives from all over the country to introduce legislation to simply recognize them as such and provide them an earned path to legal status.

Yesterday, I joined my fellow Climate Solutions Caucus co-chair Congressman Ted Deutch and the co-chairs of the Safe Climate Caucus, Representative Alan Lowenthal and Congressman Don Beyer, to urge the Administration to remain in the Paris Climate Change Agreement. Stepping away from this Agreement would mean stepping away from the immense opportunities that these international investments afford American businesses and research institutions, while fully implementing the deal will create American jobs and boost U.S. competitiveness.

South Florida residents are already beginning to feel the effects of climate change in their daily lives – from chronic flooding to coral bleaching to threats to our freshwater supply in the Everglades.  We cannot ignore these challenges and every member of Congress has a responsibility to our constituents and future generations to support market-based solutions, investments, and innovations that could alleviate the effects of climate change and make our nation more resilient.
Spoke with CBS This Morning today about the Republican Climate Resolution my colleagues and I introduced earlier this week. Tune in to CBS tomorrow morning around 7:45am to watch!

Climate change is a reality we face every day here in South Florida. While chronic flooding in the Keys and Miami Beach or salt water intrusion into the Everglades are local issues, the issue of climate change and protecting the environment is a national and international issue. I won't stop working with Republicans and Democrats toward consensus and bipartisan solutions.

I invited U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt to come visit South Florida to see the real impact climate change has on our community every day and urged him to reconsider his reckless comments about carbon emissions.
Met with Archdiocese of Miami's Archbishop Wenski in Washington to discuss immigration reform and my #RACact, which provides a pathway to legal status for Dreamers.
‪Met with Miami Jewish Health Systems to discuss how I can help them continue their great work offering comprehensive care to South Florida's seniors.‬

Agree with John McCain's calls for a Select committee to investigate any and all possible contacts between campaign and government officials and the Russian government or its intelligence services. We must ensure our elections and government are not being improperly influenced by Russia.

Was able to answer some of the calls to my D.C. office from #FL26 constituents earlier today. I know the lines have been busy, but please know my staff and I are doing our best to answer as many calls as possible. Thank you for taking time out of your day to share your thoughts on today's healthcare vote.

I knew crafting legislation to repair our healthcare system and ensure it operates more efficiently would not be easy, and we must take time to weigh all considerations. It remains critical that more be done to assist the most vulnerable in our communities, which is why I will work with my colleagues in favor of solutions that will improve this proposal. Our country deserves a healthcare system that puts patients first. That’s my goal.

Today's rollback of emission standards is misguided. We see the effects of climate change firsthand in South Florida, resulting in rising sea-levels, bleached coral reefs, and salt water intrusion, and it is also a threat to our national security and local economies across the country. We cannot, and must not, ignore these challenges. Weak environmental policies ultimately lead to the destruction of jobs and quality of life. I hope the Administration will work with me and my colleagues in the Climate Solutions Caucus to Act on this in a responsible, bipartisan way going forward.

Met with some of the great local leaders of Key Largo, Islamorada and Marathon yesterday to discuss the Florida Keys' clean water projects. This is a priority for me and my staff, and I'm grateful these officials took time to come to Washington to share the importance of this project with us.

This week I co-sponsored a bipartisan bill that will protect Jewish Community Centers across the country from the recent wave of threats by doubling the federal penalty for a bomb threat from 5 years to 10 years, and providing the Department of Homeland Security $20 million in funding to help these community centers harden their security and make people feel safer.

Honored to join CHCI’s Advisory Council. Young Hispanics have an incredible opportunity to make a positive impact on their communities and our nation, and I look forward to working with my colleagues and the CHCI staff to help these young men and women reach their fullest potential.

This most recent attack is another example of Bashar al Assad’s sick obsession with remaining in power, even if that means resorting to brutal tactics that kill his own people and continue to destroy the country. Bashar al Assad is a terrorist and has no place in the community of world leaders.     Tragically, this attack and others like it could have been avoided. Our country, under the leadership of the previous Administration, and our democratic allies around the world share the blame for Assad’s crimes against humanity. The red line for using chemical weapons against civilians was ignored and the deal with Russia to remove these weapons from Syria was clearly a charade. Regrettably, the new Administration has thus far failed to inspire confidence on Syria by stating just last week that Assad abandoning power is no longer a priority. This is unacceptable. The President and the State Department should reconsider before more innocent civilians and children are gassed to death.

Last week, Monroe County coordinated with 3 federal agencies, the U.S. Coast Guard and two state agencies to remove 31 derelict vessels from the Marquesas Keys. This project has not only restored the shoreline and nearshore habitats, but also removed these hazardous vessels so they don’t pose a threat to visitors or the environment. Good to see local and federal authorities working together for the benefit of our community.

Over the years many immigrant children have arrived in our country – brought by their parents who either illegally crossed one of our borders or overstayed their visas. For most of these young people, the United States is the only country they have ever called home. They attended school with our own children, graduated high school and today they are seeking to serve in our military, pursue a college degree or certificate and contribute to our economy by working. Earlier this week, The 700 Club highlighted some of their stories and my bill, the Recognizing America's Children Act, which would provide them an earned path to legal status.

After years of impunity and the deaths of over 500,000 people, last night, for the first time ever Bashar al Assad was held accountable for his despicable conduct. No world leader can get away with gassing innocent children to death. This action was long overdue. I applaud the Administration's resolve in the face of evil, and I'm proud that our country ended the world's silence over  Assad's grotesque genocide that has claimed the lives of so many in Syria. The world is better when U.S. stands for justice. This sends a strong message that America will lead.

As a former School Board member and the father of two young children in public school, it’s of great importance to me that schools across the country are a safe place where students can learn and thrive without being subject to bullying or harassment. We need to support policies that promote healthy learning environments and empower students to succeed, while also reducing the risk of avoidable tragedies that can cause incredible pain for families and communities. The legislation I introduced with Rep. Linda Sánchez this week is an important step toward achieving these goals.

Last week, Congressman Marc Veasey and I introduced bipartisan legislation to help in our nation’s fight against climate change by making carbon capture technology more attainable. Carbon capture technology is an innovative, common-sense solution that allows our nation to continue working towards more efficient sources of energy that better protect the environment. By making it easier and more affordable for power plants and industrial facilities to invest in the infrastructure updates needed to make carbon capture possible, this bipartisan legislation would reduce the carbon emissions that are scientifically proven to hurt our environment while protecting and creating American jobs.

Grateful to have some of our nation’s most beautiful National Parks in our district. #NationalParksWeek starts tomorrow and continues until April 23rd. Be sure to head out to Dry Tortugas National Park, Biscayne National Park or Everglades National Park and get free entrance to enjoy some of our nation’s greatest natural wonders right here in South Florida April 15-16 and April 22-23.

Great to see Florida’s Low Income Pool will receive robust funding after the previous Administration’s drastic cuts. We must ensure Florida’s most vulnerable residents have access healthcare and that the institutions that serve them get properly reimbursed.
Enjoyed speaking with so many Monroe County constituents today. Thanks to Florida Keys Electric Cooperative, FKEC for hosting me.
From our family to yours...
Celebrating #NationalParkWeek at Everglades National Park's Shark Valley today! Proud to have such a unique and important natural treasure right here in South Florida.

Checking out the construction of phase two of the Tamiami Trail bridge project that once completed will increase water flow to the Shark Valley Slough by 80%, helping restore water flow to our Everglades.

Congressman Ted Deutch and I joined WPLG Local 10 / Local10.com's This Week in South Florida to discuss the situation in Syria, U.S.-Russia relations, and the future of the fight against ISIS over the weekend. Check out our interview here:

My family and I stopped by The Turtle Hospital in Marathon this weekend to see the great work they're doing to rescue, rehabilitate and release endangered sea turtles to their natural habitat. We must work to protect them and our oceans.

Joined Congressman Ted Deutch to urge the Administration ro remain in the Paris agreement:   “It is imperative that we maintain our seat at the table in global discussions of how to address the threats posed by climate change. The world’s leading nations must work together to not only reduce the impact carbon emissions have on climate change, but also mitigate and prepare for the effects, which communities like ours are dealing with every day. Remaining in the Paris Agreement will strengthen American leadership on environmental stewardship and help transform today’s low-carbon investments into trillions of dollars of clean energy prosperity. On the other hand, withdrawing would mean squandering a unique opportunity to promote American research, ingenuity, and innovation.   “It’s our hope the Administration will take a responsible approach on this issue. We stand ready to work with Administration officials to maintain the U.S. commitment to the agreement and secure a future of new economic opportunities and a cleaner and safer world for rising generations.”

Had a great time exploring Everglades National Park's Shark Valley earlier this week. Remember its #NationalParkWeek and entrance to all our National Parks is free this weekend. #FindYourPark at www.nps.gov/findapark
‪It was nice getting together with constituents at the district office this week. I’ve had to spend a lot of time in D.C. this year, and it’s good to be home.‬

The 2015 quarantine on South Dade’s farming community took a toll on the local farmers who were unable to bring their crops to market. Though the quarantine was necessary to protect the rest of the region from the invasive Oriental Fruit Fly, our growers took a hit from which they have yet to fully recover. As our farming community works to put food on our table, they deserve for us to have their backs when disaster strikes. I’m proud to lead with my colleagues in this effort and grateful for their support of South Dade’s farming community.
Met with restaurant owners from across our district to discuss what needs to be done to keep creating new jobs and growing our economy.

GrandDaddy's Farm Fresh Market right here in South Florida is paving the way as a clean energy-powered small business with its wind and solar powered fresh produce stand. Enjoyed visiting today with PBS NewsHour to try some of their fresh produce and shakes, and discuss the importance of innovative clean energy to our environment and our economy.
This #EarthDay, give thanks for this incredible planet we call home and recommit to protecting it for future generations.

This is exactly why the U.S. must stay in the Paris Agreement. Our communities and our country are on the frontlines of sea level rise and we need to keep our seat at the world table regarding climate change.
Congratulations to Archimedean Upper Conservatory Charter School and the six other Miami-Dade County Public Schools that made U.S. News and World Report's list of 100 best schools in the nation!

Small businesses, families and individuals need a fairer, simpler tax code to continue creating jobs and growing our economy in South Florida and across the country. That's what tax reform is all about and that’s why I'm committed to making sure we build the kind of tax code that the American people deserve.

#ThrowbackThursday to my time in Key West Monday. Thanks to the Key West Chamber of Commerce  leaders, Key West City Commissioners, members of the Women's March Florida-Florida Keys Chapter, Monroe County's United States Department of Veterans Affairs Director, and students at Key West High School for making time to discuss the issues impacting our community with me.
This Holocaust Remembrance Day, a South Florida Holocaust survivor’s message was an important reminder of our responsibility to do all we can to eliminate hate from our society and our world.

Hoy tuve el honor de reunirme con el activista y defensor de los derechos humanos en Cuba, el doctor Óscar Elías Biscet. Admiro al Dr. Biscet por su valor y por su compromiso con la libertad y la dignidad de todos los cubanos.

While the Affordable Care Act has helped some Americans, the reality is, for many the law is falling short. Over 1,000 counties across the country, including Monroe in South Florida, are left with a single insurance provider, meaning fewer choices, lower quality, and higher costs. I refuse to condemn my community and the country to a health care system burdened by ever-increasing costs, fewer options, government threats and fines against citizens, rampant fraud, inefficiency, and mismanagement. So along with my colleagues, I’ve been working on legislation to create a truly patient-centered healthcare system where every American has access to quality care.   This proposal builds off the positive aspects of the ACA that have strong bipartisan support, such as prohibiting discrimination against women, allowing young Americans to remain on their parents’ plans, and assuring protections for those suffering from preexisting conditions. By working with likeminded colleagues from all across the country, since this legislation was first filed we have secured $38 billion dollars in additional funding to support the most vulnerable Americans and to bolster maternity, mental health services, and access to healthcare for those suffering from pre-existing conditions.   For weeks I had indicated a major priority for me was for the Department of Health and Human Services to restore Florida’s Low Income Pool funding, which had been drastically and unfairly cut by the previous Administration. These funds support important safety net hospitals, like Jackson Memorial in South Florida. Recently, Secretary Price authorized $1.5 billion dollars in additional funding, which will help compensate these hospitals and their doctors for care provided to poor and undocumented residents, and for the many millions who remain uninsured under the ACA.   Today’s vote is just a step in the legislative process for this bill – not the end of it. We have worked hard to improve the legislation, but we have a long way to go. I have received assurances that the concerns I maintain will be addressed in the Senate, and for weeks I have been in contact with several offices there to make sure we are working collaboratively. A major priority is to increase the resources available to lower-income Americans and those approaching the age of retirement. I will continue listening to my constituents, doctors, health professionals, and other experts to make sure our decisions are as informed as possible. I approach this issue with a great deal of care and sobriety. For me this isn’t about ideology, partisan politics or presidential legacies, it is simply about building a sustainable healthcare system that empowers every American to make the best decisions for themselves and their families, and supports the neediest in our society. It's about putting patient interests first and above the special and government interests that have controlled the healthcare system for far too long. Now this process continues.
